title: Re: So, I hear that those Americans have been voting for stu
hmmm...
content:
I voted. I don't follow politics closely enough to give an unbiased report of the situation, but I'll do my best:

Democrats have won majorities in both the House + Senate for the first time in over a decade, and they're anticipating a broad change in perspective... so certain factions are practically dancing in the streets at the results.

We've got a "lame duck" session of congress coming up, where the Republicans will do their best to get their final say in, as majority. Should be interesting, to hear the debates on either side of those issues.

Bush remains president until 2008, and Schwarzenegger is still governing California (where I am).

title: Re: hmmm...
content:
That's about the size of it. I'm excited to have a Democratic majority, but more because I consider any change from the old bunch to be a good one than because I have fondness for the Democrats.

In local news, my state voted to protect stem cell research.

It's like America is finally starting to turn around.________________
[img]http://img80.imageshack.us/img80/8498/missouriansf9.png[/img]

title: Re: dsfl
content:
The election took place on November the nineth.

The Democrats (Bush's opposing party) took both the house and the Senate (Both of our legislative branches of government), and I'm pretty sure they took over a majority of the governer seats that were open as well.


Things don't look good for Bush, but the conservative Judiciary branch is still in place (And will be for years to come), so that'll be interesting.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...
